title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.16.3 | 09-01-2023
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Om Agyanati Miran Dhasya Gyananjan Shalakaya Chakshurun Militam Yena Tasmai Shri Gurave Namaha
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and mantras, invoking blessings and paying respects to the spiritual master and Lord Krishna.

segments.key_quote: Maharaj Parikshit, after having selected Kripacharya for guidance as his spiritual master, performed three horse sacrifices on the banks of the Ganges.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the verse from Srimad Bhagavatam describing Maharaj Parikshit performing horse sacrifices and the significance of these events.

segments.key_quote: It appears from this verse that interplanetary travel by the denizens of higher planets is easy.
segments.summary: The speaker explains Srila Prabhupada's purport, focusing on the ease of interplanetary travel for demigods and their presence at sacrifices performed by influential kings.

segments.key_quote: A pure devotee, a first class devotee, is respected and honored everywhere in the whole universe.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the nature of demigods, their subtle bodies, and the exceptional circumstances under which they appear on Earth, emphasizing the respect accorded to pure devotees.

segments.key_quote: Similarly, the demigods also become visible to the common man by their own grace.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that demigods and Krishna are not generally visible to common people but can become visible by their own grace, similar to Krishna's avataras.

segments.key_quote: Because Krishna's form or body is completely spiritual. It's not material like our body.
segments.summary: The speaker reinforces the idea that Krishna and demigods have spiritual bodies and are visible only by their own will, highlighting Maharaj Parikshit's influence in making the demigods visible.

segments.key_quote: The kings used to organize such sacrifices for the welfare of the entire citizens.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the lavish spending by kings during sacrifices, emphasizing the importance of pleasing the devatas, sages, and brahmanas, and comparing the king's charity to a cloud distributing rain.

segments.key_quote: The charity made by the kings in such sacrifices are but another form of the taxes collected from the citizens.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that the king's charity during sacrifices is a redistribution of taxes for the citizens' benefit, leading to prosperity through the successful performance of the sacrifice.

segments.key_quote: Satisfied citizens will never organize agitation against the king.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the liberal distribution of charity during sacrifices, leading to citizen satisfaction and stability in the monarchical state, emphasizing the king's responsibility for the citizens' welfare and spiritual guidance.

segments.key_quote: Without such guidance, one cannot make progress in spiritual life.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the necessity of a spiritual master for guidance, even for advanced devotees like Maharaj Parikshit, highlighting that spiritual progress requires guidance from the right authority.

segments.key_quote: Acharya means he is identified as the universal teacher. He teaches by his example.
segments.summary: The speaker defines the qualities of an acharya and a bona fide spiritual master, emphasizing their spotless character, exemplary life, and Vaishnava qualification, necessary for achieving self-realization.

segments.key_quote: Thank you very much. Hare Krishna.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes the lecture with gratitude and the Hare Krishna mantra.
